oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Bob McDill Interview
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is an interview of Bob McDill. The interview takes place on 11/12/1982.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Bob McDill
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side One - (0:19) -- Interviewer asks Bob McDill about Mel McDaniel. Bob McDill mentions working with Anne Murray and Don Williams. (1:20) -- Interviewer asks Bob McDill about "Right In The Palm Of Your Hand." The song was first recorded by Crystal Gayle. (2:58) -- Interviewer asks Bob McDill about what songs were easy to write. (3:20) -- Interviewer asks Bob McDill about "Good Ole Boys Like Me." (4:10) -- Interviewer discusses his recording Walkman. (4:51) -- Interviewer asks Bob McDill about whether he plans to write more songs like "Good Ole Boys Like Me." (6:27) -- Bob McDill mentions writing for Dinah Williams. (7:02) -- Bob McDill speaks about people returning from the Midwest with southern family heritage. (9:52) -- Interviewer asks Bob McDill about his literary habits. (10:36) -- "Songwriting can be an art. It can be. It approaches art sometime. It isn't most of the time" - Bob McDill. (12:27) -- Interviewer asks Bob McDill about what song of his has been re-recorded the most. (13:13) -- Interviewer asks Bob McDill about his future plans for an album. (13:35) -- Bob McDill discusses the advantages of working from 9-5 when songwriting. (15:24) -- Bob McDill speaks about his method of working as a songwriter. (18:05) -- Interviewer asks Bob McDill about what advice he would give to new songwriters. (20:03) -- Interviewer asks Bob McDill about whether he has recently tried co-writing.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: McDill, Bob;
